Entry.2:
I arrived back to the unit on Sunday morning 
or eve
 from 'Blighty' leave, & ever since then I have had the blues in consequence of the awful change from the gaiety of London celebrating the signing of the Armistice, to cold soldering in France.

The first part of my leave was spent with Dad , in visiting & shopping by day & attending theatres by night. Mrs. Palmer visited us for the week –end & on the second Thursday of my leave we had a party at home when the Parrs, Snowy Eva his fiancé, Marie Sawyer & a couple of friends paid us a visit. It was a splendid evening, & after Parrs land Snowy left we had some dancing. 

It was gay dancing too, for Bobby a friend of Lily`s from the Land army high spirited & full of fun, set the pace in reel dancing. It was not particularly mad but irresponsible, & we enjoyed 

ourselves immensely. 

During the weekend I visited Weymouth & had a few happy hours with travelled on to Chichester & spent a fine time with Lily, watched her at work, then spent Monday night at Caterham with Mrs. Palmer .

On Tuesday I arrived in London, met Bobby & spent the evening with her at "The Boy"; got a day’s extension of leave, & spent the best part of the following day with her ending up at the "Empire" to see Clara Butterworth in the "lilac Domino". I enjoyed the play more than any other, for Clara Butterworth is a real actress.

The journey back was tragic. I spent the first cold night with one blanket at Boulogne, the second with no blanket at Roisel, & the third in the same miserable condition for most of the night, At Fresnoy le Grand. As soon as I reached the unit & found that

they were likely to stay for a few weeks, I made arrangements to commence the classes again, & we got to work yesterday afternoon in a room which was used as a class room in the pre-war days. 

We are billeted in a large girl’s school, a section to a room on the first floor, & each room has a fire. It is quite comfortable & I have been lucky enough to get a bedstead; one of those which the Germans used when they made the school into a hospital. Our charwoman is in the same road but a hundred yards away, & was probably part of a boy’s school which was run in conjunction with the other a larger one.

The authorities have asked for the names of those who left Australia in January & February 1915, probably with the idea of sending them home soon. Seeing that I left

Australia in July of that year, it seems possible that I shall be sent back in a few months – possibly four.

We are supposed to go to Germany in two day’s time. At least we are fairly certain to go to Germany, & to have march most of the way, but when we shall start is not yet known.
Entry.3: We started from Bohain at 9.30 on Saturday & marched through very miserable battle wrecked country to Massinghien, where we stayed in the same billets as the
Entry.4:
had occupied when they were there the week before. They were underground in a factory, & the beds were composed of wire netting stretched over planks, & for these we had to thank our mutual friend Fritz. 

A few days before we started it had been found out that we were to garrison & that we should have to march most of the way. Then rumours commenced of the expressed desire of Mr. Hughes, in contradiction to our Corps leader General Monash that we should not go to Germany, but go back to Australia as soon as possible. How much truth there was in this I am unable to say, 

but it was generally understood that we were not going to Germany after all.

However, Massinghien had been originally been given as the first halting place on the way to Germany, & it was certainly on the way, so when we arrived there it was impossible for us to conjecture what was going to happen.

The next morning we started at 9 
fir
 due last again & put up in a ruined house 
for
 two kilos short of Cartignies & like the previous day, eighteen kilos 
distance
 march, that evening.

Cartignies may be said to mark the border between stiffly contested country, & that country out of which the Germans were unceremoniously & quickly pushed Before Cartignies all was wrecked, & the ground showed evidence of 

regular shell fire. The town itself was untouched except for one or two rows of houses which were burned down, undoubtable by Fritz. on evacuation. Todays march was over the country from Cartignies to Beugnies which is nine kilos beyond Avesnes. This country showed itself as picturesque, despite the weather, which, after two days of clear sunshine 2 frost, was muggy & raining. The pure green of the grass, the pretty cottages which had a peace time neatness, & the woods, even in their bareness retained a dull tinge of gold, were together pleasing to the eye. Such shell free country as we came across was not large, & the shells had fallen singly where in the other country they had fallen in barrages. All of this goes to prove that 

the Germans were hastening to wards towards their Sedan when the Armistice was signed. The young lady who is the daughter of our present landlady in Beugnies ( For George Goode I got a room without much difficulty) told me that the Armistice was signed two days after the Bosche evacuated this village.

Avesnes is a large town divided into two parts, the one on the hill nearest Bohain known as Avesnes proper & the lower town this side of the hill known as Avesnelles. At the bottom of the hill the railway runs close to the road, & there we see a scene of terrible destruction. we thought at first that it was the work of our planes but I have since found out it was done by Fritz when he was forced to retreat. A whole munitions dump in loaded 

train, was blown up with great devastating effect to the surrounding earth & houses. The dump itself was just a patch of black earth covered with blackened shell cases, across which earth lay the twisted skeleton of the munition train. The road we were following crossed the railway through the train so to speak for a portion of it was on our right while the main part of the train & the dump were on our left. That part of the train which was on our right was only partly damaged; half of one truck was blown up & in the remaining corner unexploded ammunition was laid bare.

As soon as we arrived in Bengnies I set out to look for a bed. I found plenty of civilians in the village,

very little damage done by shells or bombs, but no shops open yet. That is because the civilians were on rations still, which is not remarkable remembering that the Germans have only been gone a fortnight. It can easily be seen that things are rapidly returning to normal.

We arrived in the town by a by road, but just and the barn which was allotted to B Section as a billet I found a main road. Where it leads I do not know except that it is probably north & south & therefore perhaps between Mons & south. Along this road I found a little cottage where madam was good enough to give me a room, although she already had refugees billeted on her.
Entry.5:
We have been in the village for a fortnight & now we are in the process of moving out.

The first week of our stay here we had classes, but these, on account of the very miserable cold weather, & the large number of men on leave, were not well attended. Consequently I decided to discontinue the classes & hold debates and lectures, and the plan has turned out to be a wise one, for we now have many newly 
members
 interested men in our audiences, & have been glad to see fresh faces among the debaters. My debating prestige has suffered an eclipse, by Messrs Barlow & Waites - the former a B.A. with an ambition of joining the church, with views not altruistic yet very broad – the latter a very hard headed wizened yet kindly Jewish chap. The latter was conspicuous in unit debating 

 

in the days before I re-formed the unit, but he kept well away from my institution until Hondeghen days, when he evinced a certain desire to draw nearer. Possibly the 
solidarity of the
 permanent nature of our debating society gave him a favourable impression, but it was the tactful presence of Barlow which brought him whole heartedly into it, as the result of some friendly debating they had in C Section billet.

At present we are preparing a timetable for, & discussing our intentions with regard to our stay in the next location, which will be Chateleine near Charleroi.

All ideas of going to Germany are, I believe, thoroughly exterminated. Instead I understand that we are to stay in Charleroi for a couple of months, after which the demobilization plan will come into force. They have sent the Jan &
Entry.6:
men back 

to Australia, & a short time ago they took the names of the March to June men. This, naturally raised hopes in my breast, for I would have been next on list. Unfortunately, howeve, I have since learnt that the names were taken only as a means of finding out which men to take if there was room in the convalescent transports. It is unlikely that any more will leave now, so that I must await the demobilization scheme with the hope that it will take account of service.

During 
my
 our stay in the village George Goode & I have had some very happy hours in our village with mdme, Ms, Jeanne &Louis. We have tried to add to their scanty food ration by gifts of bully beef & canteen biscuits & chocolate, although the first few days witnessed a famine in all food stuffs owing to the unrepaired railway & 

general difficulties of transport. Still, we have been able to repay in some small way their kindness in making us free in the bed room without taking any money for it, & doing such friendly service as cleaning muddy boots against our will & giving us unlimited coffee as well as cooking little dainties which we have been able to buy.

Dick Barlow has visited us many evenings, & has delighted all of them by sketching them each & individually, which he is able to do in a not inexpert manner.

Jeanne is happy & healthy looking. She was a school girl when the Germans came, & now she is a woman, not the worse for experiences since she is still able to lighten the house with her smile, & has lost no vigour in her performance of domestic duties, as many of the poor people have. The peculiar & very beautiful trait about her (to my eyes) is the sisterly affection with which she makes us at home & chums up with us, utterly in contrast to the other French girls we have been in the habit of seeing. They went to extremes. Either they were absolutely cold & distant, experience having probably taught them that that was their best plan with soldiers, or else they were on terms of intimate foolery which bordered on the coarse. The latter had probably found how far they could go with perfect safety & delighted to hover

round the boundary. Some probably went over it, for it is a question of what is generally referred to as bringing up..

Watching Jeanne at work of an evening I have discovered that she is a pretty girl, slightly sensitive to notice, - that is, not entirelly unaffected, yet very sound. I think she would respond to well to certain contingensies if necessary, & is deserving of a husband above her station. I have not fallen in love with her, but I like her a great deal; mostly I think, because she is open & bright. Even speaking French fairly well as I do, it seems hard to get to know people intimately.
Entry.7:
To-day is Sunday and the weather has been simply glorious, a great contrast to the week days. The sun shone warmly and the mud seemed a little less troublesome, although the puddles & holes were still full of soft mud.

During the day I continued to arrange matters in readiness for Charleroi, & this evening a meeting was held to elect a new secretary for the Central committee, & to discuss the arrangements. Harry McNeil, who was secretary of our concert committee, was elected secretary. The attendance at the meeting was not good, & the sporting demand – mostly of the transport was conspicuous in their apparently intentional absence.

I have noticed that they are not fond of attending such meetings, yet they seem to join in with the arrangements afterwards. Those that did attend were enthusiastic, - 

& so the tone was lively. With the anxiety of the Colonel to prevent a feeling of discontent gaining ground in the times of waiting that are ahead, a new activity is arising, & the enouie & indifference among a certain crowd of the Ambulance, seems to be passing. The debates have no doubt helped to cause this, but the departure of our old friend Mr. Garland the W.O., who though as a sergeant on the Peninsular he was popular, was of late very unpopular, has had a good effect on the attitude of the men to movements for their good. 

The new W.O. Mr. Grey, who was a Sergt. with the
Entry.8: Field Amb., arrived today, & at least will be more in sympathy with all of us. At the same time one must remember that the war is over now, & that such an attitude is therefore easier & natural.
Entry.9:
I am writing up the diary tonight in the dynamo room of a large farm a third of the way from Bengnies to Le Chatelet, which is our destination beyond Charleroi. After many false rumours of moving off we actually started off this morning, which was three weeks after we arrived. Our stay was supposed to be for one week only, but was drawn out to three by repeated postponements of our departure.

By the time we came to leave our little white cottage by the side of the main road ( which I now know goes from Avesnes to Charleroi & is only a semi main road) & I had become very much attached to the family, & particularly to Jeanne, whom I had been teaching English with not slight success.

Teaching English to a pretty 

young French girl is a nice pastime, & likely to lead to quite other results than the mastery of the language, but we did not fall in love with each other Papa & mama were very strict with Jeanne. They would not let her out of their sight where there was a possibility of her being alone with any strange young man, neither did they like her to be too free in talk & manner with our soldiers – say George Goode & I. This much I partly observed & partly received from the little girl herself.

Seeing that she had lived through the four years of German captivity without mishap, such severity was not only natural but absolutely necessary, for she had grown from 14 to 19 in that time, & had been practically isolated from the

world all the time.

I did however get very fond of Jeanne, & she got very fond of me. The whole family was very grateful to George & me for little help we were able to give in the way of food, & also for our gracious presence. It was the rebound from the "tristesse" occasioned by their late German masters, in which we found them. This was the progenitor of the feeling Jeanne had in the end, & it was ripened by the English lessons "c’est fini – allez vous en".

I am sick of eternal committees, study circles, Education officers & the whole box of tricks. 

This feeling is caused by the impossibility of reconciling classes with that awful bogey regimental law as practised by the section

 

sergeants. Another factor is the newly arrived Education Officer, who is not honest, & is very voluble. He seeks to make his office a sinecure by large promises contained in many pseudo enthusiastic words.

A rank of sergeant is to be conferred on me, & ( the question having caused me much thought & no little ) I have decided to continue to organise the classes until the falsity of such a promise may be proved. This will not prevent me I am hopeful & feel almost sure, from joining a scholarship for a university course in England, which is my immediate objective, for I have decided to continue teaching until jouurnalism is possible
Entry.10:
I woke up the following morning, bustled around & was on the way to being ready in plenty of time for "workhouse", when I discovered that my boots were gone. Search in every corner of the store, & under the old bed which Joe Riches had dragged into the dynamo room failed to unearth them & so I paraded to the Colonel as soon as I had breakfast. He immediately decided that I must go straight on to Chatelet by car. Meanwhile madame who apparently owned the electric lighted farm by the mill, was heart broken that such a thing should happen to her, the woman who many a time succoured French, English & Russian prisoners at her own peril. It must have been " said she" the stranger in a German coat who drove away 

 

in his 
car
 trap early this morning.

Archy Garlick, (now acting .C.Q. M.S.) was the only other passenger in the car which drove me off in pelting rain. After we had passed Sivry which was to be the resting place of
Entry.11:
that night, 
& had
 near the main Charleroi to France road, a spring broke & we were landed exactly outside our estaminet.

With good luck we had the rations on board (or what was the use of a C.Q.M.S.), so we worked ourselves a meal on the nice enamel stove of the madame of the Estaminet who disliked Germans & who sold a fiendish substitute for liquor at one mark per glass. Seeing that German money is all over Belgium we cannot object to dealing in it, but the rate of exchange (1 franc .25c) seems to me to be fairly high. However they are 

 

calling it in now, so we have to be wary of being in possession of it when the day of reckoning comes along.

We arrived at Chatelet at about 3 p.m. after passing through about two miles of town with tram lines complete, not to mention numerous coal mines. The hospital which I found some of the tent subs had commenced to run, was a large building built three sides round a small quadrangle reached by a small gate. I slept the night on the third floor after a trip to the "Sentimental Bloke" in company with Scotty McNeil, Monaghan & Walter Connor.

This morning I walked around the town, played the piano at the Hotel de Ville, bought some milk chocolate & unearthed the Educational building

This I found in the same street (Rue de Station) as the hospital – the main road to Namur, as it happens, & this town is some 30 kilos away. The building is on a corner, & was a grocers shop. Now it has to have the canteen on the ground floor, together with barbers, bootmakers & a recreation room; the Educational establishment on the first floor, & C section bearers at the top.

Being a corner house the rooms 
run
 are built in the form of a semi circle. Thus, on reaching the top of the first flight there is a small room to the 
right
, a medium on half left, another in front, another still half right & a fellow to the small one to the right, with the second flight going up this side of the door. 

I bagged the small room

to the left as an office & sleeping apartment; in fact I am writing in that room now, with a candle on the window ledge, & also some books, my holdall & eating gear, & the rest of my kit on the floor. My table & chair are the result of a raid. 

This afternoon I met Archie Garlick in a large State School: we were both in the same . We found what we were after, got permission from an itinerant youth (the headmaster’s son) on false pretensions, & I bagged a nice soft bottomed chair & a white card table. Archie & a satellite got chairs & pieces of wardrobe.

Tonight Dick Barlow came in to to discuss the proposition of sleeping in this room with me. Unfortunately he closed the door after him, & as it has no handle

 

we became "in the soup". I soon ended the situation by putting my foot through the door in an energetic attempt to force the lock. The panel came away almost whole, so that, as soon as the door was opened it was an easy matter to replace the splinters & camouflage the door as untouched. If it is found out. the German of 1914 will have to be blamed I fear.

To show how exact a horse shoe is formed by these rooms, at the present moment some water seeker is fiddling with the taps in the other small room & through two windows I can see him a few feet away from me. I hope he turns the tap off properly: the room is half flooded already. Thank goodness I chose the duller but prettier toned paper in place of bright blue & the risk of floods.
Entry.12:
Seeing that a month has elapsed since I last wrote in this "interesting" little book, it is now necessary to fill up the blank somewhat before going any further. As a matter of fact I am at Aust. Corps Central School on the sand dunes north of the Somme 8 km from Rue & 30 from Abbeville.

Soon after writing the matter on the opposite page, Dick Barlow went to Paris with Tony Waights & one or two others in order to get some stuff for Christmas & New Year dinner of the Unit. I felt rather jealous 
of
 from the fact that Tony Waights & Dick did not hesitate to clean out & leave our work on the 
po
 possibility occurring of a trip to Paris – however important they may have been to the success of the purchasing of eatables. On 

the other hand I may have been unduly conscientious in not have looked for trips or taking advantage of opportunities to make them.

However, when he was gone & I was left by my self to carry on I decided to start classes in the small way which the absence of Dick & Tony made imperative; a procedure which was in any case advisable owing to the fact that circumstances were not fortuitous for the extensive running of classes. The Ambulance was under strength considerable, all tent men ineffectually kept at work that classes were out of the question for them. The same applied to the special duties such as batmen, bakers,
such
 sanitary men etc. The result was that we started in a very inauspicious way, with small classes, but subsequent days

should consistent attendance & therefore the assurance of improvement of the classes were properly handled. The unsatisfactory nature of the difficulties to be met, & the increased work, added to the cold rooms, made that work unpleasant. Through moving desks about too strenuously I made myself a little sick, & the result was that I spent a miserable day in bed 
on
 at Christmas. I had, however, enlisted the services of Stuart Kidner as librarian & help & that made matters as satisfactory for me as possible.

On Friday, which was two days after Christmas I had to make the weekly visit to the
Entry.13:
Field Amb., who were at 
Charlopoi
 ,near us, we reached them by
Entry.14:
tram by way of Charleroi. It was a clear old day, and I was

only too glad of the change involved in such a trip. By the time I reached the tram terminus of Lad`hui it had commenced to rain hard & blow fiercely & coldly. The rest of the story up to my return from
Entry.15:
Field is of transition from the cold of the muddy road to the misery of the mess hall; & thence to the warmth of the estaminet where Lt. Lowe had his office; from this warmth, helped by what Lt.Lowe called a spot & what I called a drink, to the wonderful music & food of the Sgts mess; thence from that happiness to the 
happiness of
 another form experienced in a brisk walk in a sate of exultation after the music, in the cold if bleak atmosphere.

Almost my last words to Sgt Phillips 
were
 (who was on the 

 

page missing

him, of course, Tony Waights, who, however left for Blighty the next day 
then
 from then till Thursday night when we had our next dinner, Dick was too busy with the arrangements to spend any time on classes, but on Friday he commenced taking his classes & a rapid improvement in attendance was thus made.

The Unit Dinner was a grand affair, of long white covered tables, & a band, not to mention the presence of the Mayor. Owing to the prevailing customs being hard if not impossible to alter, we found the dinner 
drag
 dragging on to a matter of four hours, so the toasts & speeches were introduced before it was finished in order to give the Sentimental Blokes a fair go; what was my

 

surprise to find that the harpist of this orchestra, whom I had noticed when I attended their opening show in Chatelet, but had not recognised as Frank Pisano who used to play with Rita in orchestras in Grafton. Truly the A.I.F. is a wonderful meeting place. I had imagined him still in Grafton.

 

Last stage of all

We arrived from France on
Entry.16:
and went straight from Southampton to Codford camp.

Previously we had a week in Belgium just before exams (visited Dunkeque, Bruges, Brussels, Waterloo Ghent. Also four days leave at home by a wangle .

Codford

Fourteen days leave - conspicuous among others by river trips (3). One with Bobby, one with Hills, & one with Hills . Called on Mrs. Palmer, Uncle Sam, Ivy, Printers School Snow Eva– wife at Streatham, & had good time with Hills.

Weeks extension granted. Sams again & made proper friends with Eileen. Hills again.

Took a week & cycled to Bournemouth. Called on everybody & had a good time 

 

Meanwhile boats allotted to us:

Prinz Hubertus to sail
Entry.20:
23rd

Then came another four days in London after the 9th was arranged. Spent with Kit again & Hills.

Arrived back & found again put back to
Entry.21:
Strike of men against continual postponements. One day’s fatigues not done. Was chief delegate & did not enjoy it. 

Final date given as
Entry.22: – more leave granted. Did not take leave. Instead I went to Stockton got a room, and started studying & working on the Short story course which I had paid £10 for. Worked until
Entry.24:
morning & embarked by tea time

on the Main.
Entry.25: morning pulled out from Berth, & moved to buoy. Then in afternoon sailed downed to harbour mouth & again buoyed up after many turns round to regulate the compass.
Entry.26:
Morning. Steamed through heads on our way, but had not gone far before steering gear went wrong. Speed down to about 3 knots & slowly steamed up & down coast while they endeavoured to fix it up. Finally had to return to Devonport.

16th We are still just within the harbour, & understand we are to sail to night or tomorrow morning.

26th-29th Devonport
Entry.27: The following are speeds up to date. We started from Devonport at 12 noon roughly on
Entry.32:
279 m

The boat has a fair amount of deck space, but this is taken up by fixtures, and in any case is insufficient for the numbers on board.

We have a promenade deck on both sides amidships open to troops and families alike. Above that is the boat deck forward half of which is for officers 2& first class passengers ( who are few), and the aft half except on isolation sections for troops above. The aft half deck is for families & troops; the forward one for troops. Aft for steerage passengers (wives etc) & forward
Entry.33:
troops only.

This arrangement gives the troops a 
maximum of at
 the most space possible and does not give the women a fair chance. However, it would be useless to further restrict the room.

Owing to the accidents which occurred in England the crew came to regard this as an interesting, if not mysterious ship. Only one breakdown has occurred, and that was soon remedied, with the loss albeit of a few miles in the days running. 

Coincidences have happened in & around this ship.

We left England in on exactly the same day of the month I left Australia to come over. That was only three days later in the month

than the day I originally left England. Further, I have met Marshall the troublesome A.M.C. chap who left with me on the Suffolk. He is taking his wife back and appears to have aged somewhat. He is however improved I imagine.

Classes are now running smoothly, and I am putting every available minute into English and Latin.

There is a girl on board who reminds me of Rita when I met her on the Rangitara. She is younger – coarser slightly but she has the same immature beautiful eyes. I have spoken to her as a result of discovering that her father is Totty, late of the third. She is very simple, but a nice good girl.
Entry.35:
284 miles

There has been a distressing accident today.

At about 11.45 a cry went up of "man overboard". I was on the forward well deck and saw several of the men rush aft at the sounding of the siren four times. Immediately a boat was lowered from the port side, & pulled around into the wake we had left behind us. Meanwhile the ship had turned right around so that we could see the lifeboat bobbing about in the wake off our starboard side. Several lifebuoys & belts were to be seen floating towards us from our late course, but no sigh of the man.

He was one of the husbands and had fallen off the poop deck right at the stern.

Soon another boat was lowered fro the starboard side, taking a little longer 

through jamming. The other was now 
abt
 only to be seen at intervals for the sea had become choppier. The second boat proceeded to search round, picking up the buoys on the way. Once all these were found it soon became apparent that little hope remained.

Nevertheless the lifeboats 
were to be
 carried on their work, and it was not until about 1 that they returned. I helped to pull one up the first & found it a tremendous strain.

Now the poor wife is left with one child – the expectation of another.
Entry.36:
259 miles

This was less on account of the ship yesterday.

 Note in orders today, that Geddes was lost at sea to our deep regret; all offering condolences to widow & child etc. Was told today that the seamen found one of the buoys smashed right up,

pointing to the presence of sharks. Many sharks seen today. Small hope for man in these seas.

Weather very hot, & canvas swimming bath 
in fwd
 on forward promenade deck, very much in demand.

Crowds line sides looking at porpoises and flying fishes. Classes very tiring below decks in close atmosphere.

Am working fairly well. Completed
Entry.37: of Cicero’s Pro Milone & well on the way with Henry VIII.
Entry.41:
254?

Boat drill today at 4 as usual. This week we have been given the first dose of yet another inoculation. Sports have been held yesterday and today

The weather at Dakka was terrible. Hot & close. After we left there it was little better. The first evening the humidity increased until a sudden wind storm relieved the 
air
 pressure somewhat. Since then there has been more movement of the boat, consequently some of the ladies have suffered. Being at the stern end, it is natural that the steerage ones should feel it. I pitied them during the hot weather. 

Today for a time it was brilliant & clear. Tonight it is overcast yet 
the
 at sunset a beautiful yellow glow came from the western clouds, & the sea was that harmonious blend of dark blue and shining orange, that I love so well.
Entry.42:
254

Shorter distance covered explained by the fact that something went wrong with a propeller, or at any rate some breakdown occurred which resulted

 

our running on one engine. This afternoon the boat has been going at something like its old speed.

Early morning communion & morning service at which I helped with distributing the books as usual I have been attending the 6 oclock services every evening down in the aft hold, but ommiting the Sunday evening services.

There is one on at present, a memorial service for Geddes who went overboard.

The weather today has been splendid. This afternoon I lay down & had a splendid sleep & sun bath.
Entry.43:
Today like Sunday we travelled very slowly all morning on one engine & only went 248 miles. The mileage is going from bad to worse.

During the week we had two good lectures by P.W.F. Wallace: one

on Bourke & the other, this evening, on dialect words in dictionaries & in relation to Standard English.

Christian work is proceeding along the lines of unity laid down by the Padre. Tonight, the usual order was named by a Salvationist taking us in the manner & with the hymns of his sect – in short nonconformist. Despite my antipathy to the type of hymns I found the meeting just as helpful if not more. 

Rumours of the week: (1) Ceramic not far behind us, & should pass us on the way shortly (2) We are to be transhipped to Ceramic on account of the unreliability of our boat (3) Propeller gone bung entirely.

Sports have been continued during the week, and there has been the usual band orchestra & concert entertainment.

Kit inspection today.
Entry.44:
For three hours this morning the boat was stopped; rest of the day she has crawled. Another boat, a very slow one passed us in the afternoon. I understand that we shall get back to normal at midnight tonight, once all repairs will be finished then. After we should make a good speed.

Boxing contests tonight, a dance & also Jazz band invitation down below. The last enough to make a cat laugh.

Setchell told me some illuminating things concerning faith really practised among such as the Plymouth Brethren. Some instances he gave me of his own results were truly remarkable.

Parliament opens on Monday with as leader of the Government & myself as leader of the opposition.
Entry.45:
Arrived Cape Town

Ashore this evening with Padre
Entry.47: Left at 2.30 pm for Durban. Boat rolled badly. Many sick. Almost stopped opposite lighthouse
Entry.48:
218 miles (Sunday) 

Going better but still rolling heavily.

Services as usual 

Meeting in afternoon. " Reconstruction from Christian Standpoint"
Entry.49: 248 miles. Classes recommenced. Rumoured pay tomorrow. Badly needed on all hands.
Entry.51:
Arrived Durban last night. Anchored all night off harbour, noticing the twinkling lights of town & wharves. Ship rolled pretty badly. 6 am started to move towards land from which we had drifted a considerable distance, and went at very slow speed.

Speed increased as both boats with unpronounceable names seemed to be gaining on us. We gave her a run for it then, & finally steamed in ahead of her at 14 knots.

Leave & pass only by launches since anchored in mid stream. No launches appeared before dinner. Afterwards many noises because 
frequent
 husbands objected to , & were thus not allowed on leave Speeches etc etc – women very noisy.

Sydney

 

 

Afternoon the main Parliament held its second service when several lady members spoke on behalf of their husbands who were busily equipped in discovering a certain principle. Mr. Paterson who replied for the Government, was often interrupted with irrelevant & facetious remarks, but despite an urgent desire on the part of one lady to do something more than talk ( at which she shone enough Heaven knows!), he held his own by the aid of his winning smile.

Later he drowned his sorrows in the comparative hilarity of a launch ride to town

Entry.65:
Nearer & nearer to land so that Durban should not be overlooked.

Nearly put into East London in mistake, because of similarity of their town halls.

Can this be the main which is forging ahead at a found speed of 11 knots?
Entry.66: Found Durban last night but such was the speed of the boat that it was found impossible to stop her short of Zanzibar. Turned around & made Durban by morning. Dutch boat sighted overhauling us rapidly. The let her get level, then with a speed which shook everybody off their feet she dashed ahead just in time to prevent miss Campbell signalling a hearty welcome to Herr Hertzog, who was on the Dutch boat.

Entry.68:
This being the day of rest the Main is to be commended in having made better headway. She is now pitching as well as rolling. General financial depression as a result of gay life in Cape Town. Unaccountable popularity of pay staff. Many offers of refreshment in harbour.
